awd_titl_txt: SHF: Small: Ferroelectric Transistor based Coupled Oscillators for Non-Boolean Computing
awd_abstract_narration:
Since conventional computing architectures based on Boolean processing of inputs may be sub-optimal for tasks involving recognition and sensory processing, exploration of new non-Boolean computing technologies has the potential to assume an important role. This project aims at addressing this issue by investigating new post-CMOS devices and circuits, and extensively analyzing their implications at the application level. The research outcomes are likely to have a direct impact on critical applications such as computer aided diagnosis, speech/face recognition, data classification and resource allocation, and benefit several areas such as healthcare, defense, and security. Moreover, power savings achieved with the proposed techniques may translate to longer battery life for mobile systems facilitating a richer user experience and ultra-low power processing. The project will enhance graduate and undergraduate education by integrating the research outputs in the curriculum. The participation of under-represented groups will also be encouraged.

The proposed research utilizes the emerging technology of ferroelectric transistor to design novel low power and compact oscillators by translating the inherent non-linearity of the ferroelectrics to sustained oscillations. A multitude of such oscillators, whose dynamics can be controlled, are coupled to realize a non-Boolean computing fabric. The extent of synchronization amongst the oscillators provides information about the degree of match/mismatch amongst different signals, enabling efficient decision-making for applications such as pattern matching, motion sensing and others. The proposed approach involves extensive co-design of devices and circuits to harness the unique features offered by the ferroelectric transistors for enhancing the energy- and area-efficiencies of the coupled oscillators.  The research effort spans different levels of design abstraction including (i) the exploration of novel ferroelectric based devices amenable for the proposed approach, (ii) new oscillator designs, and (iii) a comprehensive application-level analysis. Extensive benchmarking of ferroelectric based oscillators will be performed against previously explored oscillators to comprehensively quantify their benefits and trade-offs. In addition, detailed investigation establishing the relationships between the device-circuit characteristics and the inherent properties of the ferroelectric materials will be carried out to uncover the fundamental attributes of the proposed oscillators and their rich oscillation dynamics.

por.por_cntn:
This project conducted the exploration of coupled oscillators based on ferroelectric transistors (FeFETs) with the motivation of utilizing the unique characteristics of FeFETs (such as non-linear hysteretic current-voltage characteristics and effective negative capacitance) to enable energy-efficient dynamical systems.

Towards that end, FeFETs were comprehensively modeled using a rigorous phase-field approach to capture the multi-domain effects, based on which design space for different modes of operation of FeFETs was established. For example, non-hysteretic effective "negative capacitance"  was shown for highly scaled ferroelectric thickness based on soft domain displacement. Similarly, hysteretic polarization switching via hard domain growth and nucleation was predicted for larger ferroelectric thickness. In addition, insights into the effect of other design knobs of FeFETs (such as the gate dielectric) and material parameters (such as the elastic coefficient of the ferroelectric) on the FeFET operation were provided.  A compact model for FeFETs was developed utilzing the insights from the phase-field model to design FeFET oscillators and their coupled networks.

The design of the oscillator involved implementing a highly compact Schmitt trigger and using output-to-input feedback to generate oscillations. Sustained oscillations were observed in simulations for both flavors of designs i.e. those based on FeFETs with non-hysteretic negative capacitance effect as well as hysteretic polarization switching. Voltage controllability of the oscillation frequency was  achieved by changing the effective resistance of the feedback path. Furthermore, it was shown that the oscillation dynamics can be dynamically reconfigured between relaxation type and sinusoid-like by utilizing an additional transistor. The proposed design was shown to achieve much higher frequency of operation and robustness compared to a previously proposed FeFET based design. 

Next, the coupled dynamics of the proposed oscillators were investigated. It was shown the a rich set of coupling behavior can be obtained by employing input-to-input and output-to-ouput coupling (where input and output refers to the terminals of the Schmitt trigger). Furthermore, the implications of different kinds of coupling (such as those based on capacitance and resistance and the combinations, thereof) were analyzed.  A comprehensive design space exploration was conducted to establish the optimal range of coupling parameters and their effect on the phase synchronization of the oscillators. 

In a collaborative effort, the application of the proposed coupled oscillatory systems was explored for edge detection. For that, a convolutional neural network (CNN) was employed and the FeFET based coupled oscillators were utilized for computing the L2 norm. It was shown that the proposed fabric was able to achieve close match with the ideal output and was robust towards noise due to process variations and device-circuit non-linearities. 

This project led to the participation of 3 Ph.D. students, including a female student. The models for FeFETs developed in this research were shared amongst multiple researchers (both in academia and industry) for the exploration of new circuit solutions and to explain the physical operation of FeFETs. The novel insights provided by the FeFET models into their functionality have deepened the understanding of this intriguing technology, which can potentially be utilized to advance its application for next generation computing.  The research outcomes were integrated in a graduate course on Advanced VLSI Design offered by the Elmore Family School of Electrical and Computer Engineering at Purdue University. The students were exposed to a highly relevant field of osciilatory networks and received deep insights into the operation of ferroelectric transistors, which are of great interest in the community. With the knowledge, the students are expected to conduct further research to advance these areas, or apply their knowledge in industry to implement future generation of computing platforms. 

The research in this project has established the design of highly energy-efficient and compact coupled oscillators, which are expected to considerably advance the design of future electronic systems equipped with artificial intellgence (AI) accelerators. This can have a direct impact on critical areas such as security, defense and health. The proposed solutions will be particularly useful for AI systems deployed on edge devices which have tight energy and area budgets.  

In summary, this research has unraveled how the unique features of FeFETs can be utilized for the implementation of coupled oscillators, and has considerably advanced the modeling and physical understanding of the multi-domain ferroelectric transistors. At the same time, this project has also contributed to posing some key questions to guide future research in this area. Some key aspects that need to be further explored are the effect of  the stochasticity in FeFET polarization switching on the oscillator design and functionality, ferroelectric material attributes that are most suited for coupled oscillatory dynamics, a rigoruous abstract mathematical model for the oscillation dynamics etc.
